sentence: A reversal in oil and profit-taking pressure in consumer stocks after disappointing quarterly results from Walmart ( WMT ) extinguished Wall Street's three-day rally, and left stocks slightly negative on Thursday.
Energy was the worst performing sector of the S&P 500, but it was paced by losses in nearly every other sector except defensive sectors like utilities and telecoms.

The Dow straddled the flatline for most of the day, overlooking mixed economic data as an unexpected fall in initial jobless claims was offset by a below-consensus improvement in the Philadelphia Fed Business Outlook index and as-expected decline in leading indicators.
Oil turned south mid-morning when a government official from Saudi Arabia was quoted by Reuters as saying that the kingdom is "not prepared" to make any type of production cuts.

With the added pressure of higher-than-expected inventory data from the Energy Information Administration ( EIA ), oil retreated off $32 per barrel to close the day with a loss of more than 1%, taking equities lower in sympathy.
Stocks were also undermined by profit-taking in the consumer sector amplified by lowered guidance from Dow component stock Walmart ( WMT ).
Despite beating Q4 EPS estimates, the retailing giant missed revenue estimates and said 2016 sales would be flat compared to earlier estimates for growth of 3%-4%.
Walmart's losses weighed on the Dow and caused other component consumer stocks like Home Depot ( HD ) and McDonald's ( MCD ) to lose more than 1%.
Friday's economic calendar is light with just the CPI at 8:30am ET.
Consumer prices are expected to contract 0.1% in January, but increase 0.1% excluding food and fuel prices.

Here's where the markets stood at the close:

(+) IM (+22.56%) To be acquired by Tianjin Tianhai Investment for $38.90 in cash

(+) ATHX (+16.55%) Announced positive results from follow-up data from its Phase 2 clinical study of intravenous administration of MultiStem cell therapy
